items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is mostly dry for the weekend, with some light rain possible Sunday evening.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. Water levels in the River Mole have fallen overnight between Leatherhead and Cobham and are now below the level that we expect them to cause flooding. Some standing flood water may still remain on lower lying land around the river. There is some further rain the forecast over the next five days but we do not expect any further flooding at this time.

River levels on the Roding have continued to fall during the day and are back to within normal levels.
The risk of flooding has now reduced and levels are no longer a concern. 
No further flooding to low lying land and roads is expected

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

The Western Rother is still high in Fittleworth, following Wednesday's rain. Minor flooding may still be affecting fields and gardens in Fittleworth. The river is now slowly falling along the length of the Western Rother, so flood impacts should slowly ease, returning to significantly lower levels by Sunday 24/10/2021. In Liss, Sheet, Iping, Stedham, Midhurst and communities on the Lod, river flows are already near normal. The weather forecast is for predominantly dry days until Tuesday, but with the possibility of showers Sunday and Monday. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if flood risk returns.

The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. The water level in the Eastern Yar is now slowly falling. More unsettled conditions and showery rain return from Sunday (24/10/21) and into the early part of next week for Hampshire and the Isle of Wight. Should this rain affect the river, then we may need to issue further advice. Please remain prepared for on going minor impact flooding over the next week. We continue to monitor the forecast, and will remove any reported blockages.

The River Ouse is continuing to fall near Barcombe, following Wednesday's heavy rain. River flows all along the upper Ouse have now fallen to near normal. Minor flooding may continue to affect fields and roads near Barcombe particularly. Flooding impacts should ease on the Ouse by Saturday 23/10/2021. The weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than the chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. Some roads mentioned in this message may still have minor flooding, so please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing and reduce flood risk. We will reissue this message if flood risk returns.

The River Arun is still high between Newbridge near Billingshurst and Pallingham Lock, following Wednesday’s rain. However, water levels are now falling, and the weather forecast is for five predominantly dry days, other than showers Sunday and Monday. Minor residual flood impacts including water in fields and on roads and near isolated riverside buildings could remain until Sunday near Pallingham Lock, but will continue to ease. The river flow through Horsham, Broadbridge Heath and Wanford has already returned to near normal. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them, while residual flood impacts remain. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

The River Arun is still high near Pulborough, but is now falling following Wednesday’s heavy rain. Minor flooding will likely continue to affect fields, gardens and roads near Pulborough through the weekend, while the river is still much higher than normal. However, with a predominantly dry week ahead in the weather forecast, flood impacts and standing water should ease as river flows will continue to reduce over the next few days. At Houghton Bridge near Amberley, peak water levels will also fall over each coming day, as the tides at Littlehampton are forecast to be smaller than they have been. Our pumps in Pulborough will continue to run, to help reduce the risk of flooding. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them, while residual flood impacts remain. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
The next high tide is forecast to reach 4.792 metres at 16:45 and the following tide will be lower. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is mostly dry for the weekend, with some light rain possible Sunday evening.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels continue to fall steadily on the Middle reaches of the Dorset Stour.  The forecast is dry today and maybe a shower tomorrow Sunday.  The Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area and flooding of roads and low lying land may still be possible.  River levels are falling slowly at the Hammoon gauge.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.  Plan driving routes to avoid minor roads which are close to the river as they might still be affected by flooding. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 24/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from high tides at the Tyne and Wear Coast has now reduced. We will continue to monitor the situation.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are falling on the River Thame and Chalgrove Brook but still remain high in the Thame area. Therefore flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue in the Thame area but the risk of flooding is reducing. 
No further rainfall is forecast today. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 23/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is still likely for today, Saturday 23rd October, and into tomorrow.  Water levels continue to remain high, but are expected to soon start to drop back down to more normal levels. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.  The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 24th October.

The weather forecast is mostly dry for the weekend with the possibility of some light rain on Sunday afternoon.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.06 m and is stable. 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.
Pumping is not currently taking place at Huish Episcopi pumping station. Relatively dry weather is forecast over the next 24 hours. The River Yeo at Muchelney has been decreasing slowly throughout yesterday, 22/10/21, and into today.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated by 17:00 on Saturday, 23/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: River levels are now below the flood risk thresholds, and are slowly returning to normal. The forecast is mostly dry for the weekend, with some light rain possible Sunday evening.  Flood water may still be present in some areas, and river levels may remain higher than normal for a few days, until water can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. A Flood Alert remains in force on the Lower Stour
The forecast is dry until mid day on Sunday 24/10/2021 when further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are rising steadily, but there is no longer a risk of properties being flooded
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The River Arun is still high near Pulborough, but is now falling following Wednesday’s heavy rain. Minor flooding will likely continue to affect fields, gardens and roads near Pulborough through the weekend, while the river is still much higher than normal. However, with a predominantly dry week ahead in the weather forecast, flood impacts and standing water should ease as river flows will continue to reduce over the next few days. Our pumps in Pulborough will continue to run, to help reduce the risk of flooding. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them, while residual flood impacts remain. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.message: The Flood Warnings for the Lower Stour in Dorset have been removed but a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area.  The forecast is dry today and maybe a shower tomorrow Sunday.  The Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area and the flooding of roads and low lying land may still be possible.  The river levels in the Wimborne area have peaked and are slowly starting to fall.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.  Plan driving routes to avoid minor roads which are close to the river as they might still be affected by flooding.  This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 24/10/2021, or as the situation changes.
